1121825862591098880.text:
If you're concerned about #DEX liquidity limitations, Totle has resolved this issue by integrating with multiple decentralized exchanges to tap into a large supply of DEX liquidity and at the best prices available. 

We can use DEXs effectively now.

1121825861878132737.text:
#DEXs are the solution. 

DEXs will become the dominant exchange services in the #DeFi space.

1121825861068558336.text:
Some centralized exchanges have acted ethically but that’s beside the point. They shouldn’t have a choice. There’s a huge difference between “won’t” and “can’t”. 

If something unethical can happen, and it has, what's stopping it from happening again?

1121825860070400001.text:
Decentralized exchanges (DEXs) don’t have the luxury of using fractional reserves for the benefit of their creators. 

#DEXs won’t complete transactions if the liquidity isn’t there. Centralized exchanges accept orders, regardless of liquidity, and make withdrawing a nightmare.

1121825858753318912.text:
The lack of regulation in our industry is both a strength and a weakness. 

Since we have little regulation, we need exchanges that will function ethically regardless of whether its creators decide to act mischievously or not.

1121825858057060352.text:
.@Bitfinex and @QuadrigaCoinEx are examples of why decentralized exchanges are crucial to the adoption of cryptocurrency. 

Simply put: We can’t trust centralized exchanges to act ethically.

1012344318550568966.text: The problem we are solving at #Totle, explained in 30 seconds  #crypto #blockchain #decentralized #trading #exchange #DEX #marketpic.twitter.com/zNPB8Z2bR6

1012031859490947072.text: 11) For this industry, the #decentralization of #crypto asset #exchange is essential infrastructure that will provide resiliency should governments attempt a heavy-handed ban as seen in China last year. #blockchain

1012031858631233546.text: 10.1) In the case of @Bancor, the #smartcontract facilitating this trade utilizes a precise mathematical formula to control the exchange rate between the two tokens which is based on an agreed-upon Constant Reserve Ratio (CRR)

1012031857628721153.text: 10) Smart contract-managed reserves -- Instead of having to find a buyer for the bitcoin, a user can trade with an external reserve, depositing #bitcoin into the reserve and receiving #ether in return

1012031856798322694.text: 9.1) These Relayers maintain order books and can pool their liquidity together creating a more robust #trading infrastructure. After submitting an order to the Relayer, a market maker waits for a taker to fill that order, at which point the trade is executed on the #blockchain

1012031855263133697.text: 9) Off-chain orderbooks with on-chain settlement --The @0xProject protocol, built on #Ethereum, introduced a solution in the form of #offchain orderbooks. While the execution of trades occurs on the Ethereum #blockchain, the order books are hosted by 3rd-parties called #Relayers

1012031854252384256.text: 8) On-chain orderbooks and settlements -- The architecture of the 1st gen of DEX’s was entirely #blockchain-based. Every new order or adjustment to an existing order updates the state of the blockchain. Despite protecting user privacy & security, this method is slow and expensive

1012031853249925122.text:
7) Currently, #decentralized #exchanges are being developed along three avenues:

A) On-chain orderbooks and settlements
B) Off-chain orderbooks with on-chain settlement
C) #SmartContract managed reserves

1012031852335583236.text: 6) The absence of a centralized server executing these trades on #DEX's increases the security of the #trading process. Being a #distributed #ledger-based trading system means a hacker would need to commandeer more than half the network to compromise the system.

1012031851395940352.text: 5) Since these exchanges function as #centralized #custodians of customer funds, they serve as a single point of failure liable to be targeted by both hackers & government intervention. With #DEX's however, users control their funds until such time as a #P2P trade is executed

1012031850322321408.text: 4) The bear market of 2014–2015 was triggered by the monumental #hack of #MtGox, as the Japanese #exchange saw hackers make off with 750,000–850,000 #bitcoin, worth approximately $450 million at the time. Just recently #Coinrail was hacked causing panic in the market.

1012031848921358336.text: 3) However, users have no control of their private key and hence, no control of their funds. Aside from being against the spirit of #decentralized finance, these centralized exchanges have proven to be the #Achilles heel of the #cryptocurrency #markets

1012031848053174272.text: 2) The way cryptocurrency exchanges traditionally work is as follows: A user deposits #crypto into their account and their balance on the #exchange is credited. They then utilize the exchange’s order book and liquidity pool to buy the assets they desire & sell the ones they don’t
